channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Critical Damage Dealt to Key Iranian Nuclear Site, IAEA Says
item.description: Israeli airstrikes dealt critical damage to a key Iranian nuclear facility during weekend airstrikes, according to the United Nations atomic watchdog, likely setting back the Islamic Republic’s uranium fuel cycle by months.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone, Natalia Drozdiak

media:content.media:description: Satellite view of the Isfahan enrichment facility following Israeli airstrikes in Iran, on Jun 14, 2025.

item.title: UK Sends Jets to Protect Its Military Bases Over Iran Threat
item.description: The UK is moving aircraft to the Middle East to protect its military bases, Prime Minister Keir Starmer said, as he urged Israel and Iran to de-escalate their conflict.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, during a Bloomberg Television interview at 10 Downing Street in London, UK, on Friday, June 13, 2025. "We’ve long held concerns, grave concerns, about Iran's nuclear program, and we absolutely recognize Israel’s right to self defense," Starmer said.

item.title: Hong Kong Mulls Whether Beijing Should Handle Collusion Case
item.description: Hong Kong’s security chief said the city is working with Beijing to determine whether the mainland should take control of a suspected case of foreign collusion, a move that would expand China’s influence on national security-related cases in the financial hub.
item.dc:creator: Kari Soo Lindberg

media:content.media:description: The Two International Finance Center, left, and other buildings in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, May, 26, 2021. Hong Kong's unemployment rate fell for a second straight month in April as the city slowly emerges from an extended slump fueled by the pandemic and social unrest. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel, Iran Trade Blows for Third Day With No Sign of Letup
item.description: Israel and Iran continued intense bombardments of one another for a third day, with growing international concern the conflict will spread across one of the world’s key oil-producing regions. Middle East equity markets declined.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein, Arsalan Shahla, Marissa Newman

media:content.media:description: Vehicles jam a highway as a fire blazes nearby in the oil depots of Shahran, northwest of Tehran, on June 15.

item.title: China-US Deal Didn’t Address Some Rare Earths Controls: Reuters
item.description: The trade agreement reached by US and China in London left export restrictions tied to national security unresolved, Reuters reported, citing two people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Dayana Mustak

media:content.media:description: Rare earth magnets are displayed in the showroom at Inner Mongolia Baotou Steel Rare-Earth Hi-Tech Co. in Baotou, Inner Mongolia, China, on Wednesday, May 5, 2010. A generation after Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping made mastering neodymium and 16 other elements known as rare-earths a priority, China has cornered the market, with far-reaching effects ranging from job losses and global trade to U.S. national security. Photographer: Nelson Ching/

item.title: ‘No Kings’ Rallies Draw Massive Crowds in US as Clashes Hit LA
item.description: Protesters filled streets in hundreds of cities across the US to oppose President Donald Trump’s administration on Saturday, as he held a military parade in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Maria Paula Mijares Torres, Eliyahu Kamisher

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators face off with police during the “No Kings” protest outside of a federal building in downtown Los Angeles.

item.title: Australia Prime Minister Albanese to Meet Trump at G-7
item.description: Australia’s Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said he is scheduled to meet US President Donald Trump on Tuesday during the G-7 summit in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Ainslie Chandler

media:content.media:description: Signage ahead of the Group of Seven (G-7) Leaders' Summit in Banff, Alberta, Canada, on Saturday, June 14, 2025. Group of Seven leaders are heading to a mountain resort in the Canadian Rockies this weekend for their first gathering since Donald Trump returned to the White House. Photographer: Gavin John/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Parade Displays Military Power Amid National Protests
item.description: President Donald Trump’s military parade kicked off in Washington with a 21-gun salute, tanks and troops, as well as helicopters and parachutists, as protesters in hundreds of US cities demonstrated against his use of executive power.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: Members of the military in tanks during the US Army's 250th Anniversary Parade in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, June 14, 2025. President Donald Trump's pledge to exert US power around the world is being tested in Europe and the Middle East, but this weekend offers him a chance to display that power on American soil.

item.title: Guinea Junta Sets Up Election Body For Upcoming Votes
item.description: Guinea’s military junta leader, General Mamadi Doumbouya, has created an institution that will be responsible for managing the constitutional referendum as well as upcoming political elections.
item.dc:creator: Ougna Camara

media:content.media:description: Guinea's President Mamadi Doumbouya addresses the 78th session of the United Nations General Assembly, Thursday, Sept. 21, 2023. (AP Photo/Richard Drew)

item.title: Manhunt Is On for Suspected Killer of Democrats in Minnesota
item.description: A manhunt was under way Saturday for a suspect who shot two Democratic Minnesota lawmakers and their spouses and carried a manifesto listing other politicians and abortion providers in the state.
item.dc:creator: Miranda Davis, Myles Miller

media:content.media:description: Law enforcement officers including the FBI stage less than a mile from a shooting in Brooklyn Park, Minnesota, on June 14.

item.title: Violeta Chamorro, Nicaragua’s Former President, Dies at 95
item.description: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the Nicaraguan leader whose rule in the 1990s marked the end of the country’s civil war and who served as Latin America’s first elected female president, died on Saturday at 95.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro following her inauguration in Managua in 1990.

item.title: Starmer Indicates Prospect of Fresh UK-Canada Trade Talks
item.description: The UK will seek to restart trade negotiations with Canada, Prime Minister Keir Starmer said on his way to meet his counterpart, Mark Carney as he strives to strengthen commercial ties around the world to better insulate Britain’s economy from the fallout of US President Donald Trump’s tariff war.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer.

item.title: At Least 100 People Killed by Gunmen in Nigeria, Rights Group Says
item.description: ABUJA, Nigeria (AP) — At least 100 people have been killed in a gun attack on a village in Nigeria ’s north-central Benue state, Amnesty International Nigeria said Saturday.

media:content.media:description: Photo by STEFAN HEUNIS / AFP) (Photo by STEFAN HEUNIS/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump, Putin Discuss Middle East Tensions in Hour-Long Call
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin and US President Donald Trump discussed the escalating crisis between Israel and Iran in a roughly hour-long phone call on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Deana Kjuka

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin, Donald Trump

item.title: Iran Conflict Ensnares Energy as Israel Hits Giant Gas Field
item.description: The unfolding Middle East crisis extended to Iran’s energy infrastructure as Israel launched an attack on a giant gas field in the Persian Gulf, threatening further turmoil for markets.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Grant Smith, Anthony Di Paola

media:content.media:description: The South Pars Gas-Condensate field in Asalouyeh, Iran, in 2021. Photographer: Saeid Arabzadeh/AFP

item.title: Trump Earned $57.7 Million From Crypto Venture, Disclosure Shows
item.description: President Donald Trump earned $57.7 million from token sales by the crypto firm he and his sons helped launch last year, according to his required federal financial disclosure forms.
item.dc:creator: Bill Allison

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump during the Congressional picnic on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 12, 2025. Senate Republicans seeking to put their mark on the House-passed tax-and-immigration package are considering raising the state and local tax deduction cap to $30,000, lower than the House's $40,000 plan.

item.title: Iran Fires Hundreds of Missiles at Israel as Conflict Escalates
item.description: Israel extended attacks against Iran as fighting escalated between the two sides, raising international concerns of a protracted conflict that threatens to engulf the oil-rich Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Abeer Abu Omar, Golnar Motevalli, Alex Newman

media:content.media:description: Israeli rescue forces look at buildings destroyed in an overnight a ballistic missile attack by Iran, in Ramat Gan, Israel, on Saturday, June 14, 2025. Iran fired hundreds of ballistic missiles against Israel following an unprecedented direct attack on its nuclear facilities, ramping up a conflict between sworn enemies that threatens to engulf the Middle East and disrupt global oil supplies.

item.title: UK Will Launch Inquiry into Grooming Gangs, Starmer Says
item.description: The UK will launch a national inquiry into child grooming gangs, Prime Minister Keir Starmer said, in an about-turn that comes five months after rebuffing calls from the opposition Conservative Party and the billionaire Elon Musk to conduct a full probe.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators hold a banner featuring Elon Musk during a protest calling for justice for victims of sexual abuse and grooming gangs, outside the council offices at City Centre in Oldham, England, on Jan. 20, 2025.

item.title: NASA Considers Axiom Launch Next Week Following Delay
item.description: NASA is considering a Thursday launch date for the fourth Axiom astronaut mission to the International Space Station after a repair review caused a delay.
item.dc:creator: Sam Kim (News)

media:content.media:description: SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket and Dragon spacecraft at Launch Complex 39A in NASA’s Kennedy Space Center, before the launch of Axiom Space’s Axiom Mission, in Cape Canaveral, Florida, on June 11, 2025.

item.title: US Steel Sale to Nippon Steel Poised to Close After Trump Deal
item.description: Nippon Steel Corp. won conditional US approval for its $14.1 billion purchase of United States Steel Corp., capping a lengthy saga in a tie-up that will create one of the world’s largest steel companies.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Joe Deaux

media:content.media:description: Steel coils in front of a US flag at the US Steel Corporation Irvin Works facility in West Mifflin, Pennsylvania, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The US government could receive a so-called golden share - or powers akin to it - in United States Steel Corp. as a condition for approving a $14 billion takeover by Japans Nippon Steel Corp.

item.title: Iran-US Talks on Sunday Called Off After Israeli Strikes
item.description: Nuclear talks between Iran and the US scheduled for Sunday in Oman will no longer take place, after Israeli attacks on the Islamic Republic prompted retaliatory strikes that escalated regional tensions.
item.dc:creator: Omar Tamo

media:content.media:description: Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi, left, meets with Omani Foreign Minister Badr bin Hamad al-Busaidi as part of the fifth round of nuclear talks between Iran and the United States in Rome, Italy, in this handout photo released by the Iranian Foreign Ministry on May 23, 2025.

item.title: US Opposes European Push to Lower G-7’s Russia Oil Price Cap
item.description: The US isn’t budging from its opposition to a lower price cap on Russian oil sales, people familiar with the matter said, dampening European hopes that leaders meeting for a Group of Seven summit in Canada will agree to a cut.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Ben Bartenstein, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Gas pipes at the Comprehensive Gas Treatment Unit No.3 at the Gazprom PJSC Chayandinskoye oil, gas and condensate field, a resource base for the Power of Siberia gas pipeline, in the Lensk district of the Sakha Republic, Russia, on Monday, Oct. 11, 2021. Amid record daily swings of as much as 40% in European gas prices, Russian President Vladimir Putin made a calculated intervention to cool the market last week by saying Gazprom can boost supplies to help ease shortages. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: Egypt Postpones Opening of Flagship Museum Amid Regional Tension
item.description: Egypt postponed the long-anticipated inauguration of its flagship antiquities museum amid the ongoing military confrontation between Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Sherif Tarek

media:content.media:description: Visitors look out towards the Giza pyramid complex as they tour the Grand Egyptian Museum in Giza, Egypt, on May 5.

item.title: Thiam’s Party Holds Protest After Exclusion From Ivorian Vote
item.description: Ivory Coast’s main opposition party took to the streets Saturday after its candidate, former Credit Suisse AG Chief Executive Officer Tidjane Thiam, was barred from contesting in this year’s presidential elections.
item.dc:creator: Kamailoudini Tagba

media:content.media:description: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast supporters attend a rally for Tidjane Thiam in Abidjan, on May 3. Photographer: Issouf Sanogo/Getty Images

item.title: Russia, China to Lead Construction of Two Kazakh Nuclear Plants
item.description: Kazakhstan has selected Russia’s Rosatom to lead a consortium for the construction of its first nuclear power plant. The China National Nuclear Corp. expected to be lead a group to build a second atomic facility.
item.dc:creator: Andrey Biryukov, Nariman Gizitdinov

media:content.media:description: Workers do welding on a part of a RITM-200 nuclear reactor at ZiO-Podolsk Machine-Building Plant, an enterprise of Russia's nuclear agency Rosatom machine-building unit, in the town of Podolsk in the Moscow region on Dec. 5, 2023.

item.title: Portugal Aims to Meet Defense Spending Goal of 2% of GDP in 2025
item.description: Portugal said it aims to reach a target for investment in defense to represent 2% of gross domestic product in 2025, reaffirming a plan to accelerate spending in the sector.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: A Portuguese Military UAS (Unmanned Air System) drone during a NATO exercise in 2022. Photographer: Patricia De Melo Moreira/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Iran’s Araghchi Says US Talks ‘Unjustified’ After Israeli Attack
item.description: Iranian foreign minister and lead negotiator, Abbas Araghchi, said continuing nuclear talks with the US would be “unjustifiable” in light of Israel’s ongoing military assault on the Islamic Republic, according to a government statement.
item.dc:creator: Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi Photographer: Tatyana Makeyeva/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Zelenskiy Says US ‘Decisiveness’ Key to Pressuring Putin
item.description: Ukraine needs clarity from the US about steps to put pressure on Russia toward a ceasefire, since European support hinges on it, President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said ahead of the G7 meeting in Canada, where he hopes to meet President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Kateryna Chursina

media:content.media:description: Volodymyr Zelenskyi

item.title: Iran’s Nuclear Sites Hobbled But Not Destroyed, Experts Say
item.description: Israel’s airstrikes damaged Iran’s nuclear program but likely fell well short of eliminating it, experts said, presenting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the US with a quandary on what to do next.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: A poster displaying the portraits of Iranian military generals and nuclear scientists, killed in Israel's attack early on June 13, hangs from a lamppost in Tehran on June 14, 2025. Israel's military said that its fighter jets were set to resume striking targets in Tehran, after announcing it had hit air defences in the Iranian capital area overnight, as Israel and Iran trade fire with such intensity for the first time following decades of enmity and conflict by proxy, with fears of a prolonged conflict engulfing the region. (Photo by Atta KENARE / AFP) (Photo by ATTA KENARE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: The Big Gulf AI Deal That's Divided the White House
item.description: What does AI dominance actually mean?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: The White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. US President Donald Trump said he would be increasing tariffs on steel to 50% from 25%, saying the move would help protect American steelworkers during a visit to a United States Steel Corp. plant on Friday.
